ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This class was outstanding and very useful for my field of study. The topics discussed were current and information provided was excellent. This class should be taught every year.
This was a truly excellent course. I was really impressed with the dedication both professors showed, as well as the expertise.

Very interesting, discussion-based course. I appreciated the amount of thought that Sara and Lauren clearly put into considering our discussion topics and student input; they both provided a lot of insight into some of the deeper implications of the papers we discussed.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The seminar structure of this course, which was based on weekly readings and discussions, was a great way to address and wade through some of the thorny issues associated with invasive control. I also found the end-of-semester debates to be an excellent want to highlight many of the complexities facing modern day environmental managers and policymakers when it comes to addressing invasive species.
Because we had to write a response to questions every week, everyone in the class was equally engaged from a variety of view points.
I love discussion based classes, and this one certainly didn't disappoint. For me, this is a far more effective way to learn than weekly lectures.
It was a real treat to work with Sara and Lauren -- they are both very thoughtful and insightful, and good at directing discussions in interesting ways.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I might suggest expanding the formal lecture component slightly each week.
Maybe one field trip to a sight where land managers were dealing with invasives every day. I think it should be a three credit class.
I can think of no room for improvement.
I would have preferred to have discussed slightly fewer papers -- it would have allowed more time for me to focus on the material.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing needed to change.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Because I am a land manager this class provided extremely useful information that I could implement immediately into my management strategy.
This course helped me to reconsider the role of invasive species in contemporary ecosystems, and to view them as dynamic ecosystem components rather than simply "bad."

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Invasive species management is a particularly pertinent issue in urban land conservation, and I wanted to improve my knowledge in this realm.
I am very interested in understanding the role that invasive species will play in the face of climate change.

I took this course to 1. learn about a topic that I have personal interest in but little academic experience and 2. improve my performance during in-class discussions. I feel that both aspects were successful.
I have a long-standing interest in invasive species.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Yes, they exceeded my expectations.
Yes! And then some. Lauren and Sara were wonderful class leaders, and they really pushed my previous opinions/ideas about invasive species.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: As is normal in group projects, I was able to work with a student with a different view point. Unfortunately, most of the work load was not very equally shared. This is not a reflection of the course or professors, but may be an area to focus on in the future (e.g. individual and group grade for project).

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Definitely worth it if you think that invasive species management will factor into your future professional work in any way. I will add the caveat that this class doesn't tell you how to address invasives or how to identify specific species, so if that's what you're interested in the class probably isn't for you. But if you're interested in unpacking some of the underlying theories and social and ecological complexities between species invasions, it's a fantastic course.
Take this course if you are interested in land management, forest health and policy.

Take this course! Complete the weekly reading, and take your time on the weekly responses. This course will give you what you put into it. I really enjoyed this platform for discussion each week, and highly recommend it to anyone interested in invasive species management.
